awd_titl_txt: Deciphering the ecology of aquatic single-stranded DNA phages (Microviridae/Gokushovirinae)
awd_abstract_narration:
Phage (viruses that infect bacteria) are abundant and dynamic components of all ecosystems. Through infection of bacteria, phage can affect carbon and nutrient cycles, influence bacterial diversity, and play important roles in gene transfer. Phage come in two varieties - those with double stranded versus those with single-stranded DNA (ssDNA).  It had been assumed that ssDNA phage were not important in aquatic ecosystems, but recent studies by this team suggest otherwise. As the first study of the role of ssDNA phage in inland waters, the proposed research will shed light on a previously overlooked component of aquatic ecosystems. Project results will provide the first insight regarding the abundance, diversity, and ecology of ssDNA phages in natural freshwater habitats. In addition to training graduate and undergraduate students, outreach will encourage teenage girls to pursue STEM fields through creating hands-on learning modules for an Oceanography Camp for 8th Grade Girls at the University of South Florida and through involvement with local Girl Scout troops. 

This proposal will study the diversity and ecological roles of the ssDNA phages known as gokushoviruses (family Microviridae, subfamily Gokushovirinae) by focusing on two ground-fed springs and associated aquatic ecosystems in Florida. Preliminary studies in one of these springs indicated low ssDNA phage diversity, simplifying evaluations of spatiotemporal variability and improving the likelihood of discriminating specific phage-host associations. This research combines quantitative and qualitative methods to analyze the distribution of gokushoviruses and their potential hosts, as well as lab-based microcosm studies to provide insight into the ecology of this unique viral group. Through diel, daily, and monthly sampling from three sites in each spring system, this project will determine the temporal and spatial patterns of gokushovirus abundance and diversity to test the hypothesis that the springs maintain a stable, low-diversity gokushovirus community, while gokushovirus diversity and abundance display seasonal fluctuations farther from the springs where environmental variation is more pronounced.  Through simultaneous sequence-based analysis of host and phage communities, single-cell techniques, microcosm experiments, measurements of bacterial respiration and metabolic diversity, induction assays, and culturing attempts, this project will constrain the potential host range of gokushoviruses and determine their ecological roles in aquatic ecosystems. These experiments will test the hypothesis that ssDNA phages modify bacterial community composition and ecosystem function through infection of specific bacterial hosts, some of which they are able to lysogenize. Completion of these goals will transform aquatic microbial ecology by enabling the inclusion of ssDNA viruses as a well-understood, integral component of the aquatic virome.

por.por_cntn:
Bacterial and viral communities are central to food webs and biogeochemical processes in aquatic environments, where they help maintain ecosystem health. Aquifers, which are essential underground freshwater reservoirs worldwide, are understudied ecosystems that harbor diverse forms of microbial life. However, little is known about the composition of microbial communities within these critical freshwater ecosystems. Phages (viruses that infect bacteria) are abundant and dynamic components of all aquatic ecosystems, where they affect carbon and nutrient cycles, influence bacterial diversity, and play important roles in gene transfer. This research examined the diversity and spatiotemporal dynamics of microbial communities in the high-magnitude springs fed by the Floridan aquifer system, which is the primary drinking water source for millions of people in the southeastern United States and contributes large amounts of freshwater to major river systems in Florida.

We surveyed five first-magnitude springs across the northern half of Florida to describe their prokaryotic and viral community composition. The average abundances of virus-like particles and prokaryotic cells were slightly lower than those reported from other groundwater systems. Despite all of the springs being fed by the common Floridan aquifer, sequencing revealed unique prokaryotic and viral communities in each spring, suggesting that groundwater microbial communities are influenced by land usage in recharge zones.  We then performed a temporal study (winter, spring, summer, and fall) of the same parameters from the Manatee spring outflow, the mixing zone, and the Suwanee river the spring feeds in to. The abundance of prokaryotes and virus-like particles increased 100-fold from the spring head to the river. Only a few members from the head communities persisted in the river at low abundance, suggesting the springs play a minor role in seeding downstream communities. Prokaryotic and viral communities within Manatee Springs clustered by site, with seasonal variability likely driven by water flow. As water flowed through the system, microbial community composition was affected by changes in physiochemical parameters and community coalescence. Greater temporal fluctuations were observed in prokaryotic and viral community composition with increasing distance from the spring outflow, reflecting the relative stability of the groundwater environment, and comparisons to springs from prior work reaffirmed that distinct first magnitude springs support unique communities.

As part of the viral community analyses, we were particularly interested in phages with single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) genomes, which have been largely overlooked in aquatic viral ecology.  We developed and applied methods to allow the quantitative assessment of the relative contribution of ssDNA viruses to the community. Sequences of ssDNA viruses were detected at all spring sites and dominated the identifiable sequences at one spring site, showing that these small viruses merit further investigation in groundwater systems. While numerous ssDNA virus genomes were identified in both the spatial and temporal datasets, attempts to further study their biology were unsuccessful due to the low overall viral abundances in the springs.   

Finally, we performed a broad survey of RNA viruses associated with freshwater macrophytes, a diverse group of aquatic phototrophs that are visible with the naked eye, in the Florida springs.  We identified over 150 viral contigs, 37 of which approximated complete genomes or segments. These viral contigs represented putative members from all five major established phyla of the RNA viral kingdom Orthornavirae. While the viral contigs were most similar to viruses reported from diverse aquatic hosts, including phototrophs, invertebrates, and fungi, we also detected viruses from orders dominated by terrestrial plant viruses, indicating that some members of these orders can thrive in aquatic hosts. PCR assays confirmed the widespread presence of these viruses in submerged macrophytes - which included both novel viruses as well as two well-known terrestrial plant viruses.

Project results provided novel insight into the abundance, diversity, and spatiotemporal variability of viruses in Florida?s freshwater springs. Since the health of the Floridan aquifer system and its associated springs is declining due to nutrient loading, increased urbanization ana agricultural activity in aquifer recharge zones, and saltwater intrusion, these data represent a critical baseline of prokaryotic and viral community diversity against which to compare future ecosystem change. This project resulted in a total of 12 peer-reviewed publications, one PhD dissertation, and 9 presentations at scientific conferences.  Community and K-12 education were promoted through the creation and execution of two outreach activities, one focused on phage biology and the other focused on DNA for species identification. The interdisciplinary research community was expanded through the training of 4 graduate students, 1 postdoctoral researcher, 7 undergraduate students, and 2 high school students.
